metadata.description: Comprehensive job market database designed for SQL JOIN practice. Contains real job posting data from multiple platforms, normalized into educational tables with carefully designed relationships. Features both original normalized tables (companies, jobs, skills) and educational lookup tables (job_categories, employment_types, countries, etc.) with varying complexity levels and intentional NULL values for LEFT JOIN practice.
metadata.source: Luke Barousse's job postings dataset (lukebarousse/data_jobs) from HuggingFace, enhanced with educational lookup tables
use_cases: Week 4 SQL curriculum: Practice INNER JOIN and LEFT JOIN operations
Understanding primary/foreign key relationships in normalized databases
Exploring NULL handling in LEFT JOIN scenarios
Business intelligence queries on job market data
Data analysis projects combining multiple related datasets
metadata.educational_focus: Understanding JOIN differences and NULL handling

tables.name: companies
tables.description: Master table containing all unique companies that have posted job openings. Serves as the primary dimension table for company-related analysis and demonstrates one-to-many relationships with jobs.

columns.name: company_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each company. Primary key used to establish relationships with jobs table.

columns.name: company_name
columns.description: Official name of the company. May contain NULLs for data quality issues, demonstrating real-world data challenges.

tables.educational_purpose: Foundation table for practicing basic INNER JOINs. Students learn to connect company information with job postings and understand one-to-many relationships.

tables.name: company_tiers
tables.description: Educational lookup table categorizing companies by their hiring volume (number of job postings). Contains business logic for classifying companies from startups to enterprises, demonstrating calculated JOINs and business categorization.
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE company_tiers AS
SELECT 
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY min_postings) as tier_id,
    tier_name,
    min_postings,
    max_postings,
    description
FROM (
    VALUES 
        ('Large Enterprise', 100, 99999, 'Companies with 100+ job postings'),
        ('Medium Company', 20, 99, 'Companies with 20-99 job postings'),
        ('Small Company', 5, 19, 'Companies with 5-19 job postings'),
        ('Startup/Small Business', 1, 4, 'Companies with 1-4 job postings')
) AS t(tier_name, min_postings, max_postings, description)
ORDER BY min_postings DESC;

columns.name: tier_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each company tier. Used for joining with calculated company posting counts.

columns.name: tier_name
columns.description: Business-friendly name for the company tier (e.g., 'Large Enterprise', 'Startup/Small Business').

columns.name: min_postings
columns.description: Minimum number of job postings to qualify for this tier. Used in range-based JOIN conditions.

columns.name: max_postings
columns.description: Maximum number of job postings to qualify for this tier. Used in range-based JOIN conditions.

columns.name: description
columns.description: Human-readable description of the company tier criteria and typical characteristics.

tables.educational_purpose: Advanced JOIN practice requiring calculated fields and range-based conditions. Students learn to JOIN tables using complex criteria (BETWEEN clauses) and understand business logic implementation in database design.

tables.name: countries
tables.description: Geographic lookup table containing countries where job postings are located, enhanced with regional groupings and currency information. Demonstrates geographic analysis capabilities and medium-complexity JOINs.
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE countries AS
SELECT 
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY job_country) as country_id,
    job_country as country_name,
    CASE 
        WHEN job_country = 'United States' THEN 'North America'
        WHEN job_country IN ('United Kingdom', 'Germany', 'France', 'Spain', 'Italy', 'Netherlands') THEN 'Europe'
        WHEN job_country IN ('India', 'Singapore', 'Japan') THEN 'Asia'
        WHEN job_country IN ('Australia', 'New Zealand') THEN 'Oceania'
        ELSE 'Other'
    END as region,
    CASE
        WHEN job_country = 'United States' THEN 'USD'
        WHEN job_country IN ('Germany', 'France', 'Spain', 'Italy', 'Netherlands') THEN 'EUR'
        WHEN job_country = 'United Kingdom' THEN 'GBP'
        WHEN job_country = 'India' THEN 'INR'
        WHEN job_country = 'Singapore' THEN 'SGD'
        ELSE NULL
    END as primary_currency
FROM (
    SELECT DISTINCT job_country 
    FROM locations 
    WHERE job_country IS NOT NULL
) t
ORDER BY country_name;

columns.name: country_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each country. Generated using ROW_NUMBER() for consistent ordering.

columns.name: country_name
columns.description: Official name of the country where job postings are located. Extracted from original location data.

columns.name: region
columns.description: Geographic region classification (North America, Europe, Asia, Oceania, Other). Demonstrates CASE statement logic in table creation.

columns.name: primary_currency
columns.description: Primary currency used in the country (USD, EUR, GBP, etc.). Contains intentional NULLs for LEFT JOIN practice with less common countries.

tables.educational_purpose: Geographic analysis and medium-complexity JOINs. Students practice joining location data with country information, learn to handle NULL values in currency fields, and understand regional grouping strategies.

tables.name: employment_types
tables.description: Educational lookup table for job schedule types (Full-time, Part-time, Contractor, etc.) with business classification and working hours. Intentionally includes varied data with NULLs to demonstrate LEFT JOIN behavior and NULL handling.
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE employment_types AS
SELECT 
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY job_schedule_type) as employment_type_id,
    job_schedule_type as type_name,
    CASE 
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Full-time' THEN 'Permanent'
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Part-time' THEN 'Permanent'
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Contractor' THEN 'Temporary'
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Internship' THEN 'Training'
        WHEN job_schedule_type LIKE '%Temp%' THEN 'Temporary'
        ELSE 'Other'
    END as employment_class,
    CASE
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Full-time' THEN 40
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Part-time' THEN 20
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Contractor' THEN 40
        WHEN job_schedule_type = 'Internship' THEN 32
        ELSE NULL
    END as typical_hours_per_week
FROM (
    SELECT DISTINCT job_schedule_type 
    FROM jobs 
    WHERE job_schedule_type IS NOT NULL
) t
ORDER BY type_name;

columns.name: employment_type_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each employment type. Generated sequentially for consistent ordering.

columns.name: type_name
columns.description: Original job schedule type name from the dataset (Full-time, Part-time, Contractor, etc.). Preserves original data values.

columns.name: employment_class
columns.description: Business classification of employment type (Permanent, Temporary, Training, Other). Demonstrates CASE statement logic and business categorization.

columns.name: typical_hours_per_week
columns.description: Typical working hours per week for this employment type. Contains intentional NULLs for complex/uncommon employment types to demonstrate LEFT JOIN NULL handling.

tables.educational_purpose: Perfect for LEFT JOIN practice with NULL handling. Students learn how LEFT JOINs behave when lookup tables contain NULL values, and practice filtering/handling missing data in business scenarios.

tables.name: job_categories
tables.description: Small, manageable lookup table for job title categories with business classification. Designed as the perfect starting point for basic INNER JOIN practice with clear, intuitive relationships.
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE job_categories AS
SELECT 
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY job_title_short) as category_id,
    job_title_short as category_name,
    CASE 
        WHEN job_title_short LIKE '%Senior%' THEN 'Senior Level'
        WHEN job_title_short LIKE '%Machine Learning%' THEN 'Specialized'
        ELSE 'Standard Level'
    END as experience_level,
    CASE
        WHEN job_title_short IN ('Data Scientist', 'Senior Data Scientist', 'Machine Learning Engineer') THEN 'Science'
        WHEN job_title_short IN ('Data Engineer', 'Senior Data Engineer', 'Cloud Engineer') THEN 'Engineering' 
        WHEN job_title_short IN ('Data Analyst', 'Senior Data Analyst', 'Business Analyst') THEN 'Analytics'
        ELSE 'Technical'
    END as job_family
FROM (
    SELECT DISTINCT job_title_short 
    FROM jobs 
    WHERE job_title_short IS NOT NULL
) t
ORDER BY category_name;

columns.name: category_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each job category. Simple integer sequence for easy JOIN practice.

columns.name: category_name
columns.description: Simplified job title category (Data Analyst, Data Scientist, etc.). Matches job_title_short field in jobs table for straightforward JOINs.

columns.name: experience_level
columns.description: Experience level classification (Senior Level, Specialized, Standard Level). Derived from job title patterns using CASE statements.

columns.name: job_family
columns.description: High-level job family grouping (Science, Engineering, Analytics, Technical). Useful for aggregation and GROUP BY practice.

tables.educational_purpose: Introduction to INNER JOINs with a small, manageable dataset. Perfect first JOIN exercise where students learn basic ON clause syntax and understand one-to-many relationships between jobs and categories.

tables.name: job_skills
tables.description: Junction table implementing many-to-many relationship between jobs and skills. Demonstrates advanced JOIN concepts where one job can have multiple skills and one skill can belong to multiple jobs.

columns.name: job_id
columns.description: Foreign key reference to jobs table. Part of composite primary key implementing many-to-many relationship.

columns.name: skill_id
columns.description: Foreign key reference to skills table. Part of composite primary key implementing many-to-many relationship.

tables.educational_purpose: Advanced many-to-many JOIN practice. Students learn to join three tables (jobs, job_skills, skills) and understand junction table concepts, composite primary keys, and complex relationship modeling.

tables.name: jobs
tables.description: Main fact table containing all job postings. Central hub for all relationships, connecting to companies, locations, platforms, and skills. Represents the core business entity around which all JOINs revolve.

columns.name: job_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each job posting. Primary key connecting to skills through job_skills junction table.

columns.name: company_id
columns.description: Foreign key reference to companies table. Links job postings to their hiring companies for JOIN practice.

columns.name: location_id
columns.description: Foreign key reference to locations table. Enables geographic analysis and location-based JOINs.

columns.name: platform_id
columns.description: Foreign key reference to platforms table. Tracks job posting source for data attribution analysis.

columns.name: job_title_short
columns.description: Standardized job title category (Data Analyst, Data Scientist, etc.). Used for JOINs with job_categories table.

columns.name: job_title
columns.description: Full job title as posted by the employer. Contains detailed position descriptions and requirements.

columns.name: job_schedule_type
columns.description: Employment schedule type (Full-time, Part-time, Contractor, etc.). Links to employment_types table for JOIN exercises.

columns.name: job_work_from_home
columns.description: Boolean indicator for remote work availability. Can be joined with remote_work_policies table for policy analysis.

columns.name: job_posted_date
columns.description: Date and time when job was posted. Useful for temporal analysis and date-based filtering in JOIN queries.

columns.name: job_no_degree_mention
columns.description: Boolean indicator for whether job posting mentions degree requirements. Useful for education requirement analysis.

columns.name: job_health_insurance
columns.description: Boolean indicator for health insurance benefits. Demonstrates benefit analysis and boolean data handling in JOINs.

columns.name: salary_rate
columns.description: Salary rate type (yearly, hourly, etc.). Contains many NULLs providing excellent LEFT JOIN practice scenarios.

columns.name: salary_year_avg
columns.description: Average annual salary for the position. Useful for salary analysis and numeric aggregation in JOIN queries.

columns.name: salary_hour_avg
columns.description: Average hourly salary for the position. Demonstrates handling of different salary structures in data analysis.

sample_data.job_title: Senior Clinical Data Engineer / Principal Clinical Data Engineer ...

tables.educational_purpose: Central fact table for all JOIN operations. Students practice connecting jobs with companies, locations, platforms, and skills. Demonstrates real-world data complexity with multiple foreign keys and business attributes.

tables.name: locations
tables.description: Geographic dimension table containing job locations with city and country information. Essential for location-based analysis and geographic JOINs with jobs table.

columns.name: location_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each location. Primary key used for JOINs with jobs table and educational geographic analysis.

columns.name: job_location
columns.description: Full location description (city, state/province, country). Used for detailed geographic analysis and location-based filtering.

columns.name: job_country
columns.description: Country name where job is located. Can be joined with countries table for regional analysis and currency information.

tables.educational_purpose: Geographic JOIN practice with medium-sized dimension table. Students learn to join job data with location information and practice working with hierarchical geographic data (city, country).

tables.name: platforms
tables.description: Job platform dimension table showing where job postings originated (LinkedIn, Indeed, etc.). Demonstrates simple lookup table JOINs and data source tracking.

columns.name: platform_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each job posting platform. Primary key used for JOINs with jobs table to track data sources.

columns.name: platform_name
columns.description: Name of the job posting platform (LinkedIn, Indeed, etc.). Used for analyzing job posting distribution across platforms.

tables.educational_purpose: Simple lookup table JOIN practice. Students learn basic foreign key relationships between jobs and platforms, understanding data source attribution in business contexts.

tables.name: remote_work_policies
tables.description: Educational binary lookup table for remote work policies. Specifically designed with intentional NULL values to demonstrate LEFT JOIN behavior when lookup data is missing.
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE remote_work_policies AS
SELECT 
    policy_id,
    is_remote,
    policy_name,
    policy_description
FROM (
    VALUES 
        (1, TRUE, 'Remote Friendly', 'Position allows remote work'),
        (2, FALSE, 'On-site Required', 'Position requires office presence'),
        (3, NULL, 'Hybrid/Flexible', 'Remote work policy not specified')
) AS t(policy_id, is_remote, policy_name, policy_description);

columns.name: policy_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each remote work policy. Used for JOINs with jobs table based on remote work status.

columns.name: is_remote
columns.description: Boolean indicator for remote work availability. Contains intentional NULLs for demonstrating LEFT JOIN NULL handling.

columns.name: policy_name
columns.description: Human-readable name for the remote work policy (Remote Friendly, On-site Required, etc.).

columns.name: policy_description
columns.description: Detailed description of the remote work policy and its implications for job seekers.

tables.educational_purpose: Perfect LEFT JOIN demonstration with intentional NULLs. Students learn how LEFT JOINs handle missing lookup data and practice filtering strategies for incomplete business data.

tables.name: skills
tables.description: Skills dimension table containing technical and business skills referenced by jobs. Partners with job_skills junction table to demonstrate many-to-many relationships.

columns.name: skill_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each skill. Primary key used for many-to-many JOINs with jobs through job_skills junction table.

columns.name: skill_name
columns.description: Name of the technical or business skill (Python, SQL, R, etc.). Used for skill-based job matching and analysis.

columns.name: skill_category
columns.description: Category classification for the skill (programming, database, analytics, etc.). Enables skill grouping and trend analysis.

tables.educational_purpose: Many-to-many relationship foundation. Students learn to connect skills with jobs through junction tables, understanding how complex relationships are modeled in normalized databases.

relationships.description: Self-referential relationship for employment type categorization - demonstrates lookup table design patterns
Jobs can have multiple skills - one side of the many-to-many relationship through junction table
Skills can belong to multiple jobs - other side of the many-to-many relationship through junction table
Jobs table primary key relationship - central hub connecting to all dimension tables
Each location can have multiple job postings - demonstrates geographic dimension relationships
Each platform can host multiple job postings - demonstrates data source tracking relationships
Location dimension table primary key - enables geographic analysis and country-level grouping
Platform dimension table primary key - tracks job posting sources and data provenance
Skills dimension table primary key - foundation for many-to-many job-skill relationships

schema_notes: Database contains 9 foreign key relationships ensuring referential integrity
Junction tables detected: job_skills, jobs - implementing many-to-many relationships
Normalization approach: 3NF design with fact table (jobs) and multiple dimension tables (companies, locations, platforms, skills) plus educational lookup tables for progressive learning complexity

Business logic implementation: Educational tables include calculated fields (company_tiers), geographic hierarchies (countries), employment classifications (employment_types), and intentional NULL values for LEFT JOIN practice
Performance optimization: Primary keys on all dimension tables, foreign key relationships clearly defined, junction table with composite primary key for efficient many-to-many queries
